meeting_annotations.speaker: Justin Bahl (UGA)
meeting_annotations.transcript: So so it's informed from a symptom though. so if there there's you can you know there's a respiratory disease or you're getting respiratory samples uh and then you look for presence of the virus and and the the correlation uh is is sort of what you're trying to detect there.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Efrem Lim, ASU
meeting_annotations.transcript: Correct. yeah, so so we start with the disease phenotype first and then we try to find that if I were to like, you know, engage more on the veterinary side since we have a, you know, pretty diverse group here. It's sort of like if you see you're starting a pigs starting to die, then you're like, okay, what's going on there? Should we be sequencing those cases and is there a new virus? Um on the other hand, there's also examples where I can think of where it doesn't cause disease in the natural reservoir, but then when it crosses into humans then there's like um disease. So so um you know, flu is a good example of that too or even the coronaviruses, they don't cause disease in bats. Bats aren't dying from them. But then when it comes to humans then you get a lot of disease. Um whereas there are many other examples where, you know, when you start seeing birds, waterfowl dying and from flu, then that's like a really, really bad thing because normally they infect waterfowl pretty pretty easily, I think.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Justin Bahl (UGA)
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think that's a really important point. Like like we don't want it to be just general fishing trip and finding everything. If you if you inform, I guess that gets to one of the points on the on the list. But you have to sort of inform your surveillance uh where you can't just go and get everything and and you will definitely find new viruses, like you know, go sequence lettuce, you'll you'll find new viruses.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Justin Bahl (UGA)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um whether it do any it does anything or not or has an impact uh is what people are going to care about. So so are there uh I'm I I'm trying to I'm I'm trying to keep my brain in into a um potential project uh for things.

meeting_annotations.transcript: So I kind of have a question here about so you're talking about refining surveillance. I I will just put that out there. Um so then like so there's has to be some way to target it. So one way people have done it is around disease events and sort of forward tracking, back tracking in disease events, which helps you target things. But that in some ways like from the epidemiologist standpoint, that's really biasing your sample, right? So you're missing all of the things that are going on under the radar when you do that and you tend to be looking at high consequence populations, right? So it has to be pretty big or it has to be humans or livestock mortality or something that that's kind of raising it to that level. Um can we understand the whole system just looking through those ways or are there some things that we could do to understand the system by looking at other strategies of narrowing down what we're looking at.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Efrem Lim, ASU
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I agree with Rebecca that it's not practical or feasible to say I want to sequence every wildlife out there and catalog everything. I think it's not feasible. Um one of the things that I've been thinking a lot is about I'm not I'm not anywhere close to being expert, but there's this idea of a string theory where there's a lot of data points, but you don't have to understand all the data points, you don't have to actually go sample all the data points. There are certain key parts along that network and that's sufficient to infer then downstream events.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Rebecca Garabed (Ohio State)
meeting_annotations.transcript: No one has the magic bullet on that one.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: The screen shows a photo of a herd of cattle in a field. The cattle are various colors, including brown, black, and white. The background is a green field with trees and a blue sky.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Efrem Lim, ASU
meeting_annotations.transcript: Oh, to elaborate a little bit more. So so this this came from an idea here of how we deal with contact tracing in COVID. It flips the idea of contact tracing. So in contact tracing, you have to wait till every individual that's infected then reports back to then say, hey, I'm infected. And then there's a lag time and then someone some contact tracing, some epidemiology team then follows up on that. So what you're in order to figure out of in a population, how many people are infected, that contact tracing approach requires on bottom up. Like everyone has to like every positive has to be identified.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Efrem Lim, ASU
meeting_annotations.transcript: In a alternate approach, it is that people who are not infected are as equally informative as people who are infected. And in which case there's some sort of system that then you report, hey, I'm not infected and that tells you, okay, in this cluster, there is low or no infection and then you sort of then fill in the gaps. So a negative data is actually helpful in in filling up this problem of infection and disease rather than the contact tracing approach which is solely based on information of who's positive. And I that's the kind of thing that makes me feel think that when you have a end problem of like a lot of species are being infected with different pathogens rather than sequencing every single one, you know, something like that some reverse approach may be more effective.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Rebecca Garabed (Ohio State)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hopefully Anna'll be coming back in here.
